[b]Welcome to Scavenger's Hand![/b]

Youre playing version 0.08, our very first public beta! Were excited to have you on this journey and eager to hear your thoughts.

Join our Discord server - Dungeon's Entrance, to share your feedback, report bugs, and connect with other players. Your input is crucial as we continue to refine and improve the game. (You can find the Discord button in the main menu.)

Thank you for your support!

events.comment: Other events

^ Noise generation
v Other events

content.text:
Learn the basics of the game!

In Scavenger's Hand, you basically won't need the keyboard. Because this is a public beta, I am still working on most of the mechanics of the game, but the only difference in this game is that you won't use WASD, arrows or the mouse for most of the actions; instead, you will use cards. Once you use a card, it is going to disappear, and if you don't have any useful cards, you can draw another 5 cards, completely random (random direction and count).

You will see two types of cards now:

1. The movement card - Its job is pretty simple and one of the most useful - you can move an X number of tiles in the predetermined direction (shown as an arrow above the corresponding card). You will want to have this card on you at all times and be the right direction, just in case.

2. The attack/sword card - This is currently still in progress. For now, it does pretty much nothing. Basically, its job is going to be to attack in any direction (duh) and it is going to show you the current weapon you're holding.

For more information, you can join Dungeon's Entrance, our Discord server, and you can ask us in the #scavengers-chat. We'll try to be as quick as possible when answering.

Yay! You finished the public beta levels! Congratulations!

Thanks for checking out our beta! You can join the Discord server - Dungeon's Entrance, to share your feedback with us!

Sorry if you thought there's going to be more! We promise to bring more features - enemies, secrets, generated levels and so on!

Just by joining the Discord server and leaving your opinion on the game, makes me (main developer) to work with my team and turn this from a small project to one of the best roguelike games!

<3,

aDgors

eventsFunctionsExtensions.name: RoomBasedCameraMovement
eventsFunctionsExtensions.shortDescription: Move and zoom camera to the room object that contains the trigger object (usually the player).
description: Move camera to the room that contains the trigger object (usually the player).  If desired, change zoom to show the entire room or keep zoom static.
How to use:
- Place room objects on scene
- Select camera zoom limits, how fast the camera should move, and the visible buffer around each room
- Run the "Move and zoom camera" action on every frame
- Move the trigger object (player) between rooms and the camera will center on the room that contains the trigger object.
Tips:
- Use these conditions for custom logic when changing rooms : "Camera moving", "Camera zooming", and "Room changed"
- Set "Lerp Speed" to "1" to change the camera instantly

eventsFunctionsExtensions.name: CameraZoom
eventsFunctionsExtensions.shortDescription: Allows to zoom camera on a layer with a speed (factor per second).
description: ## Description

This extension allows to zoom a camera on a layer at a given speed. The zoom speed is configurable and allows a constant as well as a variable zoom speed. An anchor point can be defined, for instance, to keep what is under the cursor at the same place on screen.
### Actions
- Zoom at a given speed
- Change the zoom with an anchor point
- Zoom at a given speed and with an anchor point

eventsFunctions.description: Change the camera zoom at a given speed (in factor per second).
eventsFunctions.name: ZoomWithSpeed

parameters.longDescription: Zoom by a factor per second. 1: no effect, 2: zoom in x2 every second, 0.5: zoom out x2 every second.
parameters.name: ZoomSpeed

eventsFunctions.description: Change the camera zoom and keep an anchor point fixed on screen (instead of the center).
eventsFunctions.name: ZoomWithAnchor
eventsFunctions.sentence: Change camera zoom to: _PARAM1_ with an anchor at: _PARAM4_; _PARAM5_ (layer: _PARAM2_, camera: _PARAM3_)

events.comment:
When zooming the vector in pixels from the center to the anchor must stay the same.
It gives this system:

/ pixel_delta(t-1) = (anchor - center(t-1)) * zoom(t-1)
| pixel_delta(t) = (anchor - center(t)) * zoom(t)
\ pixel_delta(t) = pixel_delta(t-1)

where the new center can be resolved to:

center(t) = anchor + (center(t-1) - anchor) * zoom(t-1) / zoom(t)

parameters:
GetArgumentAsNumber("AnchorX")
+ (
   CameraX(GetArgumentAsString("Layer"), GetArgumentAsNumber("Camera"))
   - GetArgumentAsNumber("AnchorX")
)
* CameraZoom(GetArgumentAsString("Layer"), GetArgumentAsNumber("Camera"))
/ GetArgumentAsNumber("Zoom")

GetArgumentAsNumber("AnchorY")
+ (
   CameraY(GetArgumentAsString("Layer"), GetArgumentAsNumber("Camera"))
   - GetArgumentAsNumber("AnchorY")
)
* CameraZoom(GetArgumentAsString("Layer"), GetArgumentAsNumber("Camera"))
/ GetArgumentAsNumber("Zoom")

parameters.longDescription: 1: Initial zoom, 2: zoom in x2, 0.5: zoom out x2...
parameters.name: Zoom

parameters.longDescription: Zoom by a factor per second. 1: no effect, 2: zoom in x2 every second, 0.5: zoom out x2 every second.
parameters.name: ZoomSpeed

eventsFunctionsExtensions.name: Sticker
eventsFunctionsExtensions.shortDescription: Make objects follow the position and rotation of the object they are stuck to.
description: This extension can be useful to:
* Stick accessories to moving objects
* Animate a skeleton
* Delete an object with another one
An example allows to check it out ([open the project online](https://editor.gdevelop.io/?project=example://stick-objects)).

eventsFunctions.description: Define helper classes JavaScript code.
eventsFunctions.name: DefineHelperClasses

inlineCode: * Update the coordinates in the basisObject basis.
* It uses the basisObject coordinates from the previous frame.
* This way, the sticker can move relatively to it and still
// Save initial values to avoid calculus and rounding errors
* Copy the coordinates to use it the next frame.
* This method is also called by children to ensure
// If the behavior on the basis object has a different name,
// the objects will still follow their basis objects
// Follow parents 1st to avoid frame delays
object.setX(basisObject.getCenterXInScene() + object.getX() - object.getCenterXInScene() + deltaX * Math.cos(angle) + deltaY * Math.sin(angle));
object.setY(basisObject.getCenterYInScene() + object.getY() - object.getCenterYInScene() - deltaX * Math.sin(angle) + deltaY * Math.cos(angle));
// Unproportional dimensions changes won't work as expected
// if the object angle is not null but nothing more can be done
// because there is no full affine transformation on objects.

eventsFunctionsExtensions.name: SmoothCamera
eventsFunctionsExtensions.previewIconUrl: https://resources.gdevelop-app.com/assets/Icons/Line Hero Pack/Master/SVG/Computers and Hardware/Computers and Hardware_camcoder_gopro_go_pro_camera.svg
eventsFunctionsExtensions.shortDescription: Smoothly scroll to follow an object.
description: The camera follows an object according to:
- a frame rate independent catch-up speed to make the scrolling from smooth to strong
- a maximum speed to do linear following ([open the project online](https://editor.gdevelop.io/?project=example://platformer-with-tilemap)) or slow down the camera when teleporting the object
- a follow-free zone to avoid scrolling on small movements
- an offset to see further in one direction
- an extra delay and catch-up speed to give an impression of speed (useful for dash)
- position forecasting and delay to simulate a cameraman response time
A platformer dedicated behavior allows to switch of settings when the character is in air or on the floor. This can be used to stabilize the camera when jumping.

eventsBasedBehaviors.description: Smoothly scroll to follow an object.
eventsBasedBehaviors.name: SmoothCamera

events.comment: Update private properties through setters to check their values and initialize state.

eventsFunctions.description: Move the camera closer to the object. This action must be called after the object has moved for the frame.
eventsFunctions.name: MoveCameraCloser

events.comment: The camera following is called with an action, the call from doStepPreEvents must be disabled to avoid to do it twice.

eventsFunctions.description: Move the camera closer to the object.
eventsFunctions.name: DoMoveCameraCloser

events.comment:
Delaying and forecasting can be used at the same time.
Forecasting only use the positions that are older than the one used for delaying.
The behavior uses a position history that is split in 2 arrays:
- one for delaying the position (from TimeFromStart to TimeFromStart - CamearDelay)
- one for forecasting the position (from TimeFromStart - CamearDelay to TimeFromStart - CamearDelay - ForecastHistoryDuration

At each frame, the camera must catchup the target by a given ratio (speed)
cameraX(t) - targetX = (cameraX(t - 1) - targetX) * speed

The frame rate must not impact on the catch-up speed, we don't want a speed in ratio per frame but a speed ratio per second, like this:
cameraX(t) - targetX = (cameraX(t - 1s) - targetX) * speed

Ok, but we still need to process each frame, we can use a exponent for this:
cameraX(t) - targetX = (cameraX(t - timeDelta) - targetX) * speed^timeDelta
cameraX(t) = targetX + (cameraX(t - timeDelta) - targetX) * exp(timeDelta * ln(speed))

pow is probably more efficient than precalculated log if the speed is changed continuously but this might be rare enough.

eventsFunctions.description: Delay the camera according to a maximum speed and catch up the delay.

events.comment: Maybe the catch-up show be done in constant pixel speed instead of constant time speed.

events.comment:
Simple linear regression
y = A * x + B

A = Covariance / VarianceX
B = MeanY - A * MeanX

Note than we could use only one position every N positions to reduce the process time,
but if we really need efficient process JavaScript and circular queues are a must.

VarianceX = sum((X[i] - MeanX))
VarianceY = sum((Y[i] - MeanY))
Covariance = sum((X[i] - MeanX) * (Y[i] - MeanY))

y = A * x + B

A = Covariance / VarianceX
B = MeanY - A * MeanX
Axis permutation to avoid a ratio between 2 numbers near 0.
Permute back axis

eventsFunctions.sentence: Project history oldest: _PARAM2_;_PARAM3_ and newest position: _PARAM4_;_PARAM5_ of _PARAM0_

events.comment:
Perpendicular line:
pA = -1/a; 
pB = -pA * x + y

Intersection:
/ ProjectedY = a * ProjectedX + b
\ ProjectedY = pA * ProjectedX + b

Solution that is cleaned out from indeterminism (like 0 / 0 or infinity / infinity):
ProjectedX= (x + (y - b) * a) / (a + 1)
ProjectedY = y + (x * a - y + b) / (a + 1)

eventsFunctionsExtensions.shortDescription: Pathfinding allows to compute an efficient path for objects, avoiding obstacles on the way.
description: In comparison to the built-in pathfinding behavior, this one aims to:
- better respect obstacle shapes
- find paths faster if obstacles don't move
The isometric example shows how to use this extension to move a character to a destination ([open the project online](https://editor.gdevelop.io/?project=example://isometric-game)).

eventsFunctionsExtensions.name: DungeonGenerator
eventsFunctionsExtensions.shortDescription: Create a procedurally generated dungeon.  Includes two layouts: "rooms and hallways" and "dungeon cave".
description: How to use:
- Run the "Generate Dungeon Cave" or "Generate Dungeon with Rooms" action at the beginning of a scene.
Tips:
- Keep the amount of space used by room objects to less than ~25% of the total map.  If you add too many rooms, they will not be placed correctly and might collide with other rooms.
- Try using top-down controls combined with physics behavior (with no gravity) on the player and wall objects
- Use external layouts to place pre-designed rooms on randomly created room objects
- Use "Delete Unused Terrain" option to reduce resources used
- Use "RoomID(object)" expression to determine the starting and ending room
- Use "NeighborCount(object)" expression to find good places to place treasure.  A high amount of neighbors means that the tile is a nook or cranny.
- Use "IsRoomEntrance" condition to identify hallway objects that are adjacent to a room
An example shows how to procedurally generate dungeons or caves ([open the project online](https://editor.gdevelop.io/?project=example://dungeon-generator)).

eventsFunctionsExtensions.name: MazeGenerator
eventsFunctionsExtensions.shortDescription: Create a maze made of a grid of rectangular cells. Walls are created randomly so that every cell is reachable through a random path through the maze.
description: Provides functions for generating mazes.
Use **GenerateMaze** action to set up a maze with a particular size and give it a name (MazeID). The maze is stored in scene variables, to be used with other functions by specifying the MazeID.
There are three other actions that create sprite objects you can use to place the maze into the scene:
**CreateMazeFloorObjects** : create tiles for each cell in the maze
**CreateMazeWallObjects**: create objects between each cell. Useful for walls
**CreateMazeCornerObjects**: create objects on the point between 4 cell corners. Can be useful to improve maze visuals
There are plenty of other helper functions for getting/setting maze properites or get helpful information. In particular:
**CheckMazeWall**: a condition to use in event sheet to test which walls exist for a cell
**FindMazePath**: creates a scene variable array containing a sequence of directions to go from one cell to another cell

Finally, there is a **MazeObject** behavior that can be attached to wall or floor objects to provide some additional helper conditions, expressions, and actions. See the example gdevelop file in the help URL for examples of its use.

eventsFunctions.description: Specify the overall size of a maze, and the size of the tile "cells" inside the maze. Walls are randomly generated to form the maze. The maze is stored in memory, and can be referenced using a name called MazeID that is chosen here. The maze generator extension comes with other actions that reference this mazeID, which can be used to create actual wall and floor objects to place the maze into the scene.
eventsFunctions.name: GenerateMaze
eventsFunctions.sentence: Create a random maze called _PARAM7_ at point x=_PARAM1_, y=_PARAM2_ of width _PARAM3_ and height _PARAM4_, made with _PARAM5_ by _PARAM6_ cells

events.comment: The maze is initialized with 4 boolean arrays (rows * columns elements), one for each direction to track presence of a wall. From a random starting point, a loop moves an index variable through the maze picking a random direction each time to remove a wall and create a path. Once there are no more adjacent cells not yet visited (another array "FloorToDo" tracks visited or not visited yet), the completed cell is removed from the "FloorInProgress" array and it goes back to a previous cell  to try additional directions from there. Once all cells are completed the resulting arrays are stored in a structure to be used with the other maze  functions
Pick a random cell to start from, append it to an array that will track the in-progress spaces in the maze
Try each direction in a random order to see if maze can build in that direction (wall exists in that direction, next cell in that direction hasn't been completed yet)

The conditions to check for each direction are:
1. Check the direction picked randomly, stored in Directions variable
2. There is a wall that could be removed to make a new path in that direction ( ...Wall arrays contain "TRUE" if there is a wall there. All walls initialize as existing then we remove some to create the path)
3. Treat the maze boundaries as impassible. For top and bottom edge, the cell Index number being moved to has to be within the total number of cells in the maze. For the left and right edge, (index Modulo # of columns = zero) for cells on the left edge, and (index Modulo # of columns = # of columns - 1) for cells on the right edge
4. Don't move to a space we have already visited before (FloorTodo array starts as true for all cells, goes to false once visited). This prevents the maze from being too easy by having too many ways to get to each cell in the maze
5. Once a valid direction is found, skip all the other directions (FoundDirection is true once a direction is found). If the first direction it finds isn't valid, then the loop repeats again to try one of the other directions instead
If no valid directions are found, the cell is completed and can be removed from the inprogress list

events.comment: Starting from the start cell, traverse through the maze picking random directions until the end cell is encountered. At each step, record the direction taken as a string in a new array.

"Floor in progress" array is initialized with starting cell number. This loop adds additional cells to the array from random directions, traversing the maze. Once no additional paths are found for a cell, it gets removed from the "Floor in progress" array. At that point the search moves back to a previous cell and looks for another direction to go in. This continues until the first cell is removed from the array (all directions explored). Thus, once the "floor in progress" array is empty, the maze traversal is complete.
If the current cell is the end cell, check if the path variable is shortest if so make it the new shortest path
Try each direction in a random order to see if no wall is there and haven't been to the cell in that direction yet

The conditions to check for each direction are:
1. Check the direction picked randomly, stored in Directions variable
2. There is no wall in that direction, add continue with next floor in that direction
3. Don't move to a space we have already visited before (FloorTodo array starts as true for all cells, goes to false once visited). 
4. Once a valid direction is found, skip all the other directions (FoundDirection is true once a direction is found). If the first direction it finds isn't valid, then the loop repeats again to try one of the other directions instead

Once all directions are checked, no new exit path found, mark the cell as processed and remove it from the "FloorInProgress" array list. Next loop will go back to previous cell (last cell now in the "FloorInProgress" list) to check if any more directions haven't been explored yet from there

eventsFunctionsExtensions.shortDescription: Generate noise values for procedural generation.
description: Noise can be useful for many procedural generation cases such as:
- Terrain, top down or side view ([open the project online](https://editor.gdevelop.io/?project=example://marching-squares-island-generator))
- Object positioning (tree, stars...)
- Curves (roads, rivers...)
- Textures (fog, milky way...)
- Screen shake
- Many other things

This extension contains expressions to generate Simplex noise values in 1, 2, 3 and 4 dimensions. A *"seed"* allows to generate the same world again later on instead of having to save the whole generated world.
Version 2.0.0 compatibility break:
- Seeds doesn't give the same result as with version 1.x.x

See alea.md for the full license.
/** Deterministic simplex noise generator suitable for 2D, 3D and 4D spaces. */
* This involves some setup. You can save a few cpu cycles by reusing the same instance.
* @param {(() => number)|string|number} randomOrSeed A random number generator or a seed (string|number).
const random = typeof randomOrSeed == 'function' ? randomOrSeed : alea(randomOrSeed);
* Samples the noise field in 2 dimensions
let n0 = 0; // Noise contributions from the three corners
// Skew the input space to determine which simplex cell we're in
const s = (x + y) * F2; // Hairy factor for 2D
const X0 = i - t; // Unskew the cell origin back to (x,y) space
const x0 = x - X0; // The x,y distances from the cell origin
// For the 2D case, the simplex shape is an equilateral triangle.
// Determine which simplex we are in.
let i1, j1; // Offsets for second (middle) corner of simplex in (i,j) coords
// A step of (1,0) in (i,j) means a step of (1-c,-c) in (x,y), and
// a step of (0,1) in (i,j) means a step of (-c,1-c) in (x,y), where
const x1 = x0 - i1 + G2; // Offsets for middle corner in (x,y) unskewed coords
const x2 = x0 - 1.0 + 2.0 * G2; // Offsets for last corner in (x,y) unskewed coords
// Work out the hashed gradient indices of the three simplex corners
// Calculate the contribution from the three corners
n0 = t0 * t0 * (grad3[gi0] * x0 + grad3[gi0 + 1] * y0); // (x,y) of grad3 used for 2D gradient
const gi1 = permMod12[ii + i1 + perm[jj + j1]] * 3;
n1 = t1 * t1 * (grad3[gi1] * x1 + grad3[gi1 + 1] * y1);
n2 = t2 * t2 * (grad3[gi2] * x2 + grad3[gi2 + 1] * y2);
// Add contributions from each corner to get the final noise value.
// The result is scaled to return values in the interval [-1,1].
* Samples the noise field in 3 dimensions
let n0, n1, n2, n3; // Noise contributions from the four corners
// Skew the input space to determine which simplex cell we're in
const s = (x + y + z) * F3; // Very nice and simple skew factor for 3D
const X0 = i - t; // Unskew the cell origin back to (x,y,z) space
const x0 = x - X0; // The x,y,z distances from the cell origin
// For the 3D case, the simplex shape is a slightly irregular tetrahedron.
// Determine which simplex we are in.
let i1, j1, k1; // Offsets for second corner of simplex in (i,j,k) coords
let i2, j2, k2; // Offsets for third corner of simplex in (i,j,k) coords
// A step of (1,0,0) in (i,j,k) means a step of (1-c,-c,-c) in (x,y,z),
// a step of (0,1,0) in (i,j,k) means a step of (-c,1-c,-c) in (x,y,z), and
// a step of (0,0,1) in (i,j,k) means a step of (-c,-c,1-c) in (x,y,z), where
const x1 = x0 - i1 + G3; // Offsets for second corner in (x,y,z) coords
const x2 = x0 - i2 + 2.0 * G3; // Offsets for third corner in (x,y,z) coords
const x3 = x0 - 1.0 + 3.0 * G3; // Offsets for last corner in (x,y,z) coords
// Work out the hashed gradient indices of the four simplex corners
// Calculate the contribution from the four corners
n0 = t0 * t0 * (grad3[gi0] * x0 + grad3[gi0 + 1] * y0 + grad3[gi0 + 2] * z0);
const gi1 = permMod12[ii + i1 + perm[jj + j1 + perm[kk + k1]]] * 3;
n1 = t1 * t1 * (grad3[gi1] * x1 + grad3[gi1 + 1] * y1 + grad3[gi1 + 2] * z1);
const gi2 = permMod12[ii + i2 + perm[jj + j2 + perm[kk + k2]]] * 3;
n2 = t2 * t2 * (grad3[gi2] * x2 + grad3[gi2 + 1] * y2 + grad3[gi2 + 2] * z2);
n3 = t3 * t3 * (grad3[gi3] * x3 + grad3[gi3 + 1] * y3 + grad3[gi3 + 2] * z3);
// Add contributions from each corner to get the final noise value.
// The result is scaled to stay just inside [-1,1]
* Samples the noise field in 4 dimensions
let n0, n1, n2, n3, n4; // Noise contributions from the five corners
// Skew the (x,y,z,w) space to determine which cell of 24 simplices we're in
const s = (x + y + z + w) * F4; // Factor for 4D skewing
const t = (i + j + k + l) * G4; // Factor for 4D unskewing
const X0 = i - t; // Unskew the cell origin back to (x,y,z,w) space
const x0 = x - X0; // The x,y,z,w distances from the cell origin
// For the 4D case, the simplex is a 4D shape I won't even try to describe.
// To find out which of the 24 possible simplices we're in, we need to
// determine the magnitude ordering of x0, y0, z0 and w0.
// Six pair-wise comparisons are performed between each possible pair
// of the four coordinates, and the results are used to rank the numbers.
// simplex[c] is a 4-vector with the numbers 0, 1, 2 and 3 in some order.
// Many values of c will never occur, since e.g. x>y>z>w makes x<z, y<w and x<w
// impossible. Only the 24 indices which have non-zero entries make any sense.
// We use a thresholding to set the coordinates in turn from the largest magnitude.
// Rank 2 denotes the second largest coordinate.
// Rank 1 denotes the second smallest coordinate.
// The integer offsets for the second simplex corner
// The integer offsets for the third simplex corner
// The integer offsets for the fourth simplex corner
// The fifth corner has all coordinate offsets = 1, so no need to compute that.
const x1 = x0 - i1 + G4; // Offsets for second corner in (x,y,z,w) coords
const x2 = x0 - i2 + 2.0 * G4; // Offsets for third corner in (x,y,z,w) coords
const x3 = x0 - i3 + 3.0 * G4; // Offsets for fourth corner in (x,y,z,w) coords
const x4 = x0 - 1.0 + 4.0 * G4; // Offsets for last corner in (x,y,z,w) coords
// Work out the hashed gradient indices of the five simplex corners
// Calculate the contribution from the five corners
n0 = t0 * t0 * (grad4[gi0] * x0 + grad4[gi0 + 1] * y0 + grad4[gi0 + 2] * z0 + grad4[gi0 + 3] * w0);
const gi1 = (perm[ii + i1 + perm[jj + j1 + perm[kk + k1 + perm[ll + l1]]]] % 32) * 4;
n1 = t1 * t1 * (grad4[gi1] * x1 + grad4[gi1 + 1] * y1 + grad4[gi1 + 2] * z1 + grad4[gi1 + 3] * w1);
const gi2 = (perm[ii + i2 + perm[jj + j2 + perm[kk + k2 + perm[ll + l2]]]] % 32) * 4;
n2 = t2 * t2 * (grad4[gi2] * x2 + grad4[gi2 + 1] * y2 + grad4[gi2 + 2] * z2 + grad4[gi2 + 3] * w2);
const gi3 = (perm[ii + i3 + perm[jj + j3 + perm[kk + k3 + perm[ll + l3]]]] % 32) * 4;
n3 = t3 * t3 * (grad4[gi3] * x3 + grad4[gi3 + 1] * y3 + grad4[gi3 + 2] * z3 + grad4[gi3 + 3] * w3);
n4 = t4 * t4 * (grad4[gi4] * x4 + grad4[gi4 + 1] * y4 + grad4[gi4 + 2] * z4 + grad4[gi4 + 3] * w4);
// Sum up and scale the result to cover the range [-1,1]

events.comment:
Create one background instance for of each state.
Only the instance for the current state is shown.
Place the label over the backgrounds.
Show the right background accordingly to the new state.

Children instances must be resized when the button size change:
- backgrounds for each state are resized to take the full dimensions of the button
- the label is put back at the center of the button

The scale is set back to 1 because it means that the parent instance has the same dimensions as the union of its children instances.

eventsFunctionsExtensions.name: PixelPerfectMovement
eventsFunctionsExtensions.shortDescription: Grid-based or pixel perfect platformer and top-down movements.
description: Games with pixel art usually use pixels bigger than actual pixels of the screen. This can lead to big pixels partially overlapping each other which doesn't look good.
This extension allows to seamlessly keep big pixels aligned when the object is stopped and still beneficiate from the high resolution of the screen to have smooth movements.
It can be used for:
* Pixel-perfect platformers ([open the project online](https://editor.gdevelop.io/?project=example://platformer-with-tilemap))
* Align top-down characters on a grid ([open the project online](https://editor.gdevelop.io/?project=example://top-down-grid-movement))

Move to the target as the movement behavior would do.

Check if the character is decelerating.
It's done in doStepPostEvent because there is no way to know if the doStepPreEvents of this behavior is executed before or after the one of PlatformerCharcter.
As TimeDelta is used, we have to be sure the last PlatformerCharcter.doStepPreEvents call used the same TimeDelta. Which means this must be done after PlatformerCharcter.doStepPreEvents.
Save the speed to detect speed changes from outside.

eventsFunctionsExtensions.name: Health
eventsFunctionsExtensions.shortDescription: Manage health (life) points, shield and armor.
description: Manage health (life) points, shield and armor.
It handles:
- Damage cooldown
- Health and shield regeneration
- Over healing
It can be used on:
- Players
- Enemies
- NPCs
- Inanimate objects (for insance breakable doors or mining rocks)
The top-down RPG example uses this extension ([open the project online](https://editor.gdevelop.io/?project=example://top-down-rpg)).
